prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request the TDM mode to cover the large line width of 520 km/s and continuum windows, with a moderate velocity resolution of ~20 km/s. We request to map CO 3-2 line and continuum emission using two array configuration to have the best spatial resolution and maximum recoverable scale. We need spatial resolution finer than 0.22" (as obtained for CO 6-5 continuum emission in our Cycle-0 program) because this resolution was not sufficient to resolve the continuum source sizes of the individual nuclei. Not knowing the accurate source sizes led to large uncertainties in the estimation of the luminosity surface densities, which prevented us from distinguishing between AGN and compact starbursts as the dominant energy sources in the nuclei. Therefore, for CO 3-2 (line and continuum) we request two configurations C36-6 and C36-4, to obtain 0.08" resolution while imaging 2.8" of extended emission, which includes emission from the two nuclei and the surrounding large-scale gas distribution. This particular science goal is for configuration C36-4.

The observed integrated CO 3-2 line flux in Arp 220 is 3674 Jy km/s (Greve et al. 2009). The line width FWHM is ~520 km/s (Greve et al 2009; this agrees with the measured line width in our ALMA 6-5 observations). Arp 220 is a compact source compared to the primary beam of ALMA so all the CO 3-2 emission will fall within the ALMA beam. To achieve one of our proposed scientific goals, we request that all the proposed 12CO transitions have approximately the same signal-to-noise, velocity and spatial resolution as we got in our ALMA cycle-0 CO 6-5 map of Arp 220. There are two merging nuclei in Arp 220 and we detected the Western nucleus with a S/N ~55 on the peak flux of 515 (Jy/beam) km/s. The velocity resolution was 20 km/s and the spatial resolution was ~0.2".
Using the observed CO 3-2/CO 6-5 line ratio of 0.91, we estimate the peak CO 3-2 flux in the western nucleus to be 470 (Jy/beam) km/s. Dividing this value by the observed line width of 520 km/s gives a peak flux of 0.9 Jy/beam in the Western nucleus. For a S/N~55, the required sensitivity is 16.4 mJy.

Dividing this value by the observed line width of 520 km/s gives a peak flux of ~1 Jy/beam in the Western nucleus. For a S/N~55, the required sensitivity is 18 mJy. Experience from our previous ALMA observations of Arp 220 in Band - 9 shows that high S/N is also needed for the self-calibration process, which is a necessity in band-9 (and likely for Band-8) for correcting phase and amplitude errors that are hard to avoid at these frequencies except in exceptionally stable conditions. The self-calibration process worked remarkably well for Arp 220; about 90% of the total line flux (measured from Herschel) was recovered.

We request to map 13CO 4-3 in configuration C36-4 to obtain 0.15 resolution (to resolve the two nuclei) while imaging 2.1 of extended emission, which includes emission from the two nuclei and most of the surrounding large-scale gas distribution.

The 13CO 4-3 line flux can be estimated in several ways. Using the RADEX non-LTE excitation code, the best-fitting model to all 13 observed 12CO lines (J = 1-0 to J = 13-12), and a 12CO/13CO abundance ratio of 45, we predict a 12CO/13CO peak flux ratio of 29 in the 4-3 line. This ratio is high (i.e., the 13CO line is predicted to be weaker) compared to what has been seen in warm molecular gas in the Galactic center (e.g., Extaluze et al 2013), where it falls in the range 8-13 for the mid-J CO lines. Kamenetzky et al (2014) argue that this Galactic Center gas is a good analogue for the warm molecular gas component found in IR-luminous galaxies such as Arp 220. Additionally, for M82 (a starburst galaxy) there are 13CO detections (from Herschel) of the J=5-4, 6-5 and 7-6 lines, for which the 12CO/13CO intensity ratios are 20, 25 and 36, respectively. We can also use the line modeling of the 12CO 6-5 line presented in Rangwala et al (2015), assuming that the J=4-3 line exhibits similar kinematics and line optical depths, as is plausible. Although this model at present only applies to a single CO transition, it incorporates important information from the line profile and kinematics that was not available for the SPIRE analysis presented by Rangwala et al (2011).
For a 12CO/13CO abundance ratio in the range 40-80, this model predicts a 12CO/13CO peak flux ratio of 12-29. Since both the abundance ratio and 12CO optical depths possess uncertainties, and obtaining high S/N in the 13CO 4-3 line is crucial to discriminating between the absorption and outflow models for the line asymmetries, we have conservatively adopted a peak 12CO/13CO flux ratio of 29 for the J = 4-3 line. This line ratio predicts an integrated 13CO 4-3 line flux of ~155 Jy km/s. The line width FWHM is ~410 km/s (Greve et al. 2009). Note that our predicted flux for the 13CO 3-2 line is 50% of the observed value (Greve et al. 2009); this detection had a low S/N so we are using the lower flux number to err on the side of caution, as it is very important for our science goals to achieve high-S/N on this line. We also note that even the brightest end of our predictions for the 13CO line fluxes would not have been detected in the deep Herschel SPIRE-FTS Arp 220 spectrum (observation analyzed by Rangwala et al. 2011).
We request that all the proposed CO transitions have approximately the same signal-to-noise, velocity and spatial resolution as in our ALMA cycle-0 12CO 6-5 map of Arp 220 (except for 13CO6-5 science goal where we ask for a lower S/N due to prohibitively long integration time in Band-9). There are two merging nuclei in Arp 220 and we detected the Western nucleus with a S/N ~55 on the peak flux of 515 (Jy/beam) km/s. The velocity resolution was 20 km/s and the spatial resolution was ~0.2. Similarily high S/N is needed to unambiguously distinguish between the outflow and foreground absorption models.
From our 12CO 6-5 observations we know that 50% of the total flux arises in the two compact nuclei, i.e., 78 Jy km/s is in the combined nuclei. The peak flux in the Western nucleus is about 60% of the compact flux, giving an expected 13CO 4-3 peak flux in the western nucleus of ~23.4 (Jy/beam) km/s. Dividing this value by the observed line width of 410 km/s gives a peak flux of ~57 mJy/beam in the Western nucleus. For a S/N~55, the required sensitivity is ~1.04 mJy.
Note; The spectral setup allows us to also obtain neighbouring HCN J = 5-4 line. But we can give up HCN 5-4 (that appears in baseband 2) and just have 2-3 continuum windows if having part of the IF overlapping the atmostpheric absorption is a problem. The baseband4 is not set up because is very close to a strong atmospheric line.

We therefore propose to spend one hour observing this line (a sensitivity of 8.3 mJy, see below). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our ALMA cycle-0 observations of the CO J = 6-5 line in Arp 220 resolved the morphology of the warm molecular gas for the first time, revealing complex new features in the morphology and kinematics of the individual nuclear disks and the large-scale foreground gas distribution surrounding them. Multiple CO transitions are needed to characterize the cold and warm molecular gas, i.e, determine spatial variation in the optical depths, excitation and column densities as well as measure any changes in the morphology and kinematics as a function of CO rotational transition. We request 12CO line and continuum maps for J = 3-2, 4-3, 7-6, 8-7 to (a) characterize the foreground large-scale gas distribution and measure its mass and excitation, (b) measure the spatial variation in excitation and kinematics by comparing the low-J and high-J lines and (c) resolve the continuum source in the western nucleus to help determine whether the source of far-infrared luminosity is an AGN or a compact starburst. We also request 13CO J=4-3 and 6-5 observations to discriminate between absorption and outflow models and to determine the 12CO/13CO abundance ratio in an extreme star formation environment.
